articles.title: Scientists switch on the world’s largest neutrino detector deep underground
articles.summary: Deep beneath southern China, JUNO has launched one of the most ambitious neutrino experiments in history. With its massive 20,000-ton liquid scintillator detector now operational, it’s poised to answer one of particle physics’ greatest mysteries: the true ordering of neutrino masses. Built over more than a decade and involving hundreds of scientists worldwide, JUNO not only promises to resolve questions about the building blocks of matter but also to open entirely new frontiers—from exploring signals of supernovae to hunting for evidence of exotic physics.
articles.content:
The Jiangmen Underground Neutrino Observatory (JUNO) has successfully completed filling its 20,000-tons liquid scintillator detector and begun data taking on Aug. 26. After more than a decade of preparation and construction, JUNO is the first of a new generation of very large neutrino experiments to reach this stage. Initial trial operation and data taking show that key performance indicators met or exceeded design expectations, enabling JUNO to tackle one of this decade's major open questions in particle physics: the ordering of neutrino masses -- whether the third mass state (ν₃) is heavier than the second (ν2).

Prof. Yifang Wang, a researcher at the Institute of High Energy Physics (IHEP) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and JUNO spokesperson, said: "Completing the filling of the JUNO detector and starting data taking marks a historic milestone. For the first time, we have in operation a detector of this scale and precision dedicated to neutrinos. JUNO will allow us to answer fundamental questions about the nature of matter and the universe."

Located 700 meters underground near Jiangmen city in the Guangdong Province, JUNO detects antineutrinos produced 53 kilometers away by the Taishan and Yangjiang nuclear power plants and measures their energy spectrum with record precision. Unlike other approaches, JUNO's determination of the mass ordering is independent of matter effects in the Earth and largely free of parameter degeneracies. JUNO will also deliver order-of-magnitude improvements in the precision of several neutrino-oscillation parameters and enable cutting-edge studies of neutrinos from the Sun, supernovae, the atmosphere, and the Earth. It will also open new windows to explore unknown physics, including searches for sterile neutrinos and proton decay.

Proposed in 2008 and approved by the Chinese Academy of Sciences and Guangdong Province in 2013, JUNO began underground construction in 2015. Detector installation started in December 2021 and was completed in December 2024, followed by a phased filling campaign. Within 45 days, the team filled 60,000 tons of ultra-pure water, keeping the liquid-level difference between the inner and outer acrylic spheres within centimeters and maintaining a flow-rate uncertainty below 0.5%, safeguarding structural integrity. Over the next six months, 20,000 tons of liquid scintillator were filled into the 35.4-meter-diameter acrylic sphere while displacing the water. Throughout, stringent requirements on ultra-high purity, optical transparency, and extremely low radioactivity were achieved. In parallel, the collaboration conducted detector debugging, commissioning, and optimization, enabling a seamless transition to full operations at the completion of filling.

At the heart of JUNO is a central liquid-scintillator detector with an unprecedentedly large effective mass of 20,000 tons, housed at the center of a 44-meter-deep water pool. A 41.1-meter-diameter stainless steel truss supports the 35.4-meter acrylic sphere, the scintillator, 20,000 20-inch photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), 25,600 3-inch PMTs, front-end electronics, cabling, anti-magnetic compensation coils, and optical panels. All PMTs operate simultaneously to capture scintillation light from neutrino interactions and convert it to electrical signals.

Prof. MA Xiaoyan, JUNO Chief Engineer, remarked: "Building JUNO has been a journey of extraordinary challenges. It demanded not only new ideas and technologies, but also years of careful planning, testing, and perseverance. Meeting the stringent requirements of purity, stability, and safety called for the dedication of hundreds of engineers and technicians. Their teamwork and integrity turned a bold design into a functioning detector, ready now to open a new window on the neutrino world."

JUNO is hosted by the IHEP and involves more than 700 researchers from 74 institutions across 17 countries and regions. "The landmark achievement that we announce today is also a result of the fruitful international cooperation ensured by many research groups outside China, bringing to JUNO their expertise from previous liquid scintillator set-ups. The worldwide liquid scintillator community has pushed the technology to its ultimate frontier, opening the path towards the ambitious physics goals of the experiment," commented Prof. Gioacchino Ranucci, Deputy spokesperson of JUNO and a Professor at the University of Milano and INFN-Milano.

JUNO is designed for a scientific lifetime of up to 30 years, with a credible upgrade path toward a world-leading search for neutrinoless double-beta decay. Such an upgrade would probe the absolute neutrino mass scale and test whether neutrinos are Majorana particles, addressing fundamental questions spanning particle physics, astrophysics, and cosmology, and profoundly shaping our understanding of the universe.
articles.reasoning: The article reports the successful activation of the world's largest neutrino detector, JUNO, which represents a major scientific and technological breakthrough with broad implications for understanding fundamental physics, astrophysics, and cosmology. The project involved extensive international collaboration and promises to answer key open questions about neutrino masses and other phenomena, offering significant real-world impact and inspiring progress in particle physics.
articles.personality_title: World’s largest neutrino detector starts work deep underground in China
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Neutrinos are tiny particles that are very hard to detect, but they are important for understanding the universe. Scientists have built a huge detector called JUNO deep underground in southern China to study these particles better than ever before.

**What happened** – On August 26, 2024, JUNO began operating after more than ten years of building and testing. It uses a giant 20,000-ton liquid detector to catch neutrinos coming from nearby nuclear power plants. The detector is located 700 meters underground to protect it from other particles, making its measurements very precise.

**Impact** – JUNO is special because it can help scientists figure out the order of neutrino masses, a big mystery in physics. It can also study neutrinos from the Sun, supernova explosions, and even the Earth itself. The detector’s size and technology are much better than before, allowing new discoveries that could change how we understand matter and the universe.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will now collect and analyze data from JUNO for many years. They also plan to upgrade the detector to search for rare events like neutrinoless double-beta decay, which could reveal if neutrinos are their own antiparticles. The experiment is expected to run for up to 30 years, providing new insights over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The JUNO detector’s successful start marks a major step forward in studying neutrinos and understanding fundamental physics.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le plus grand détecteur de neutrinos au monde démarre en profondeur en Chine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les neutrinos sont de toutes petites particules difficiles à détecter, mais importantes pour comprendre l’univers. Les scientifiques ont construit un énorme détecteur appelé JUNO profondément sous terre dans le sud de la Chine pour mieux étudier ces particules.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 26 août 2024, JUNO a commencé à fonctionner après plus de dix ans de construction et de tests. Il utilise un gigantesque détecteur liquide de 20 000 tonnes pour capter les neutrinos venant de centrales nucléaires voisines. Le détecteur est situé à 700 mètres sous terre pour se protéger des autres particules, ce qui rend ses mesures très précises.

**Impact** – JUNO est spécial car il peut aider les scientifiques à comprendre l’ordre des masses des neutrinos, un grand mystère en physique. Il peut aussi étudier les neutrinos du Soleil, des explosions d’étoiles (supernovae) et même de la Terre. La taille et la technologie du détecteur sont bien meilleures qu’avant, permettant de nouvelles découvertes qui pourraient changer notre compréhension de la matière et de l’univers.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont maintenant collecter et analyser les données de JUNO pendant de nombreuses années. Ils prévoient aussi de moderniser le détecteur pour chercher des événements rares comme la double désintégration bêta sans neutrinos, qui pourrait montrer si les neutrinos sont leurs propres antiparticules. L’expérience devrait durer jusqu’à 30 ans, offrant de nouvelles découvertes avec le temps.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le démarrage réussi du détecteur JUNO marque une avancée majeure dans l’étude des neutrinos et la compréhension de la physique fondamentale.
articles.personality_title_es: El detector de neutrinos más grande del mundo comienza a funcionar bajo tierra en China
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los neutrinos son partículas muy pequeñas y difíciles de detectar, pero importantes para entender el universo. Los científicos construyeron un enorme detector llamado JUNO, ubicado profundamente bajo tierra en el sur de China, para estudiar mejor estas partículas.

**Qué pasó** – El 26 de agosto de 2024, JUNO empezó a operar después de más de diez años de construcción y pruebas. Usa un gran detector líquido de 20,000 toneladas para captar neutrinos que vienen de plantas nucleares cercanas. El detector está a 700 metros bajo tierra para protegerse de otras partículas, lo que hace que sus mediciones sean muy precisas.

**Impacto** – JUNO es especial porque puede ayudar a los científicos a descubrir el orden de las masas de los neutrinos, un gran misterio en la física. También puede estudiar neutrinos del Sol, explosiones de supernovas e incluso de la Tierra. El tamaño y la tecnología del detector son mucho mejores que antes, lo que permitirá nuevos descubrimientos que podrían cambiar nuestra comprensión de la materia y el universo.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos ahora recolectarán y analizarán datos de JUNO durante muchos años. También planean mejorar el detector para buscar eventos raros como la desintegración doble beta sin neutrinos, que podría revelar si los neutrinos son sus propias antipartículas. Se espera que el experimento dure hasta 30 años, brindando nuevos conocimientos con el tiempo.

**Resumen en una frase** – El exitoso inicio del detector JUNO representa un gran avance en el estudio de neutrinos y la comprensión de la física fundamental.

articles.title: Thylacine's genome provides clues about why it went extinct
articles.summary: A comparison of the thylacine’s genome to other marsupials has revealed that the creatures lost genetic diversity long before humans and dingoes arrived in Australia
articles.content:
A comparison of the thylacine’s genome to other marsupials has revealed that the creatures lost genetic diversity long before humans and dingoes arrived in Australia

Thylacines were once found throughout Australia and New Guinea Robert Nickelsberg/Getty Images

The loss of crucial genes over millions of years before the arrival of humans in Australia may have left thylacines more vulnerable to extinction.

The thylacine, or Tasmanian tiger (Thylacinus cynocephalus) was the last survivor of a family of marsupials known as Thylacinidae that once lived throughout Australia and New Guinea.

Advertisement

It was extinct on the Australian mainland by 2000 years ago, with hunting by humans and competition from dingoes thought to be major reasons for their decline. After Europeans arrived in Tasmania, the animals were persecuted by farmers and a government bounty, and the last specimen died in Hobart Zoo in 1936.

Nagarjun Vijay and Buddhabhushan Girish Salve at the Indian Institute of Science Education and Research Bhopal first became interested in the genome of the Tasmanian tiger while studying the genome of the Bengal tiger (Panthera tigris tigris).

“We were seeing some parallels between the extinction of the thylacine with our own tiger,” says Vijay. “And there is a lot of impetus to conserve the tiger in India.”

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

The pair suspected that hypercarnivores like the Bengal tiger and the Tasmanian tiger have, through their evolutionary history, lost genes that may leave them vulnerable when exposed to environmental changes or new diseases.

They analysed genetic records previously recovered from thylacine museum specimens and compared them with the genome of their close relative, the Tasmanian devil (Sarcophilus harrisii), and other marsupials.

In contrast to almost every other marsupial, including Tasmanian devils, thylacines had lost at least four important genes, known as SAMD9L, HSD17B13, CUZD1 and VWA7.

Vijay says they were surprised to discover that the loss of the genes didn’t seem to occur after the Tasmanian population became isolated when sea levels began to rise about 10,000 years ago.

The loss of these genes might have had advantages under certain conditions in the past, but it potentially compromised the species’ health by reducing antiviral defences, metabolic processes, lactation and their susceptibility to cancer and pancreatitis, Vijay and Salve suggest.

Thylacines lost SAMD9L, CUZD1 and VWA7 at least 6 million years ago at a time of massive climate change – a period that saw the species increase dramatically in size and become a hypercarnivore, subsisting almost entirely on meat.

“The overall narrative has always been that it is mostly human intervention, or anthropogenic changes, that have had an effect on the extinction of thylacines,” Vijay says. “And we were thinking, maybe we will see some genes that were lost that are linked to disease and that is what we found.”

Timothy Churchill at the University of New South Wales, Sydney, says there is no doubt that climatic changes in Australia over millions of years before humans arrived led to a dramatic loss of thylacines’ genetic diversity. He says it is also possible that the gene losses reported in the new study could have made Tasmanian tigers more susceptible to disease, but confirming this would require much more research.

“It’s one of those lineages that really kind of backed itself into a corner and managed to eke out its survival in its niche for a long time,” Churchill says. “But then once canids like the dingo arrived, that was the nail in the coffin on the mainland. Then, obviously, once we made them our enemy in Tasmania, that was the end of them.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about the thylacine's genome that provides new insights into the species' extinction, advancing knowledge in genetics and conservation biology. This breakthrough has broad implications for understanding species vulnerability and extinction, which can inform conservation efforts for other endangered species.
articles.personality_title: New genetic insights reveal why thylacines struggled to survive
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The thylacine, also called the Tasmanian tiger, was a marsupial that lived in Australia and New Guinea. It went extinct in the 20th century, mainly due to hunting and competition with dingoes. Scientists have long wondered why the species became so vulnerable.

**What happened** – Researchers studied the thylacine’s genome, which is its complete set of DNA, and compared it to other marsupials like the Tasmanian devil. They found that thylacines lost important genes millions of years ago, long before humans or dingoes arrived in Australia. These lost genes helped with fighting diseases and other body functions.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that the thylacine’s extinction was not just caused by humans or dingoes but also by genetic weaknesses that built up over millions of years. Losing certain genes may have made thylacines less healthy and more likely to get sick, making it harder for them to survive changes in their environment.

**What's next step** – Scientists plan to do more research to understand exactly how these gene losses affected thylacines. This knowledge could help protect other animals today by showing how genetic health influences a species’ chances of survival.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists found that the thylacine lost key genes long ago, which likely made it weaker and helped lead to its extinction.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouvelles découvertes génétiques expliquent la vulnérabilité des thylacines
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le thylacine, aussi appelé tigre de Tasmanie, était un marsupial vivant en Australie et en Nouvelle-Guinée. Il a disparu au 20e siècle, surtout à cause de la chasse et de la concurrence avec les dingos. Les scientifiques cherchaient à comprendre pourquoi cette espèce était devenue si fragile.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont étudié le génome du thylacine, c’est-à-dire l’ensemble de son ADN, et l’ont comparé à celui d’autres marsupiaux comme le diable de Tasmanie. Ils ont découvert que les thylacines avaient perdu des gènes importants il y a plusieurs millions d’années, bien avant l’arrivée des humains ou des dingos en Australie. Ces gènes aidaient à combattre les maladies et à d’autres fonctions du corps.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que l’extinction du thylacine n’a pas été causée uniquement par les humains ou les dingos, mais aussi par des faiblesses génétiques accumulées depuis très longtemps. La perte de certains gènes a probablement rendu les thylacines moins résistants et plus malades, ce qui a compliqué leur survie face aux changements.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont poursuivre leurs recherches pour comprendre précisément l’effet de cette perte de gènes sur les thylacines. Ces connaissances pourraient aider à protéger d’autres espèces aujourd’hui en montrant l’importance de la santé génétique pour la survie.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont découvert que le thylacine avait perdu des gènes clés il y a longtemps, ce qui l’a probablement affaibli et conduit à son extinction.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas pistas genéticas explican por qué los tilacinos no sobrevivieron
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El tilacino, también llamado tigre de Tasmania, era un marsupial que vivía en Australia y Nueva Guinea. Se extinguió en el siglo XX, principalmente por la caza y la competencia con los dingos. Los científicos querían entender por qué esta especie se volvió tan vulnerable.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores estudiaron el genoma del tilacino, que es todo su ADN, y lo compararon con el de otros marsupiales como el demonio de Tasmania. Descubrieron que los tilacinos perdieron genes importantes hace millones de años, mucho antes de que llegaran los humanos o los dingos a Australia. Estos genes ayudaban a combatir enfermedades y a otras funciones del cuerpo.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo muestra que la extinción del tilacino no fue solo por humanos o dingos, sino también por debilidades genéticas acumuladas durante mucho tiempo. Perder ciertos genes pudo haber hecho a los tilacinos menos saludables y más propensos a enfermar, dificultando su supervivencia ante cambios en el ambiente.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos planean hacer más investigaciones para entender exactamente cómo afectó la pérdida de estos genes a los tilacinos. Esta información podría ayudar a proteger a otros animales hoy, mostrando cómo la salud genética influye en la supervivencia.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los científicos descubrieron que los tilacinos perdieron genes clave hace mucho tiempo, lo que probablemente los debilitó y llevó a su extinción.
